title: A Safety & Tolerability Study of Intramuscular Aripiprazole in Acutely Agitated Patients Diagnosed With Dementia
description_brief: The purpose of this trial is to test the safety \& tolerability of intramuscular aripiprazole in acutely agitated patients diagnosed with Dementia.
drug: aripiprazole (intramuscular; atypical antipsychotic; small-molecule D2 partial agonist / 5-HT1A partial agonist)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests intramuscular aripiprazole for 'acutely agitated patients diagnosed with Dementia' — agitation is a neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptom, so the intended effect is symptom control rather than disease modification or cognitive enhancement. (Supports: clinical IM aripiprazole trials for acute agitation). citeturn0search0turn0search6

Act: Extracted details — intervention: intramuscular aripiprazole; indication in this trial: acute agitation in dementia; drug type/mechanism: aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic, a small-molecule partial agonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT1A receptors. citeturn1search1turn0search7turn0search8
- Randomized trials and analyses showing IM aripiprazole reduces acute agitation (dose-ranging and comparison to haloperidol). citeturn0search0turn0search6
- Pharmacology literature describing aripiprazole as a D2 partial agonist and 5-HT1A partial agonist (mechanism). citeturn0search7turn0search8

- Product/label information for IM aripiprazole formulations (e.g., Abilify Maintena / long-acting injectable info), including boxed warning that antipsychotics increase mortality in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis (important safety context for using antipsychotics in dementia). citeturn1search1turn1search0

Reflect: Classification check — this is not a biologic or disease-modifying small molecule (no amyloid/tau targeting), nor is it framed as cognitive enhancement. It is an antipsychotic used to control agitation (a neuropsychiatric symptom), so 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' best fits. Note safety caution: antipsychotics (including aripiprazole) carry an increased mortality risk in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis per product labeling; that is relevant but does not change the category. citeturn1search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests intramuscular aripiprazole to reduce acute agitation in patients with dementia — a neuropsychiatric/symptom-control indication rather than a disease‑modifying approach. Aripiprazole’s pharmacology is defined by actions at neurotransmitter receptors (primarily dopamine D2 partial agonism and serotonin 5‑HT1A partial agonism), so the most specific CADRO match is Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search0turn0search5

Act: Extracted details from the description and supporting literature — intervention: intramuscular aripiprazole for acute agitation in dementia (clinical trial data for IM aripiprazole in dementia and acute agitation). Mechanism: aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic with high‑affinity partial agonism at dopamine D2 (and D3) and 5‑HT1A receptors and additional serotonergic activity (5‑HT2A antagonism), i.e., it acts on neurotransmitter receptor systems. Based on these intervention and mechanism details, assign CADRO category D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search1turn0search2turn0search5

Reflect: Confirmation and caveats — this is a symptomatic, neuropsychiatric intervention (not targeting amyloid, tau, inflammation, synaptic repair, etc.), so it fits cleanly in D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. Although aripiprazole affects multiple receptor subtypes (dopamine and serotonin), those are all neurotransmitter receptors and do not imply a multi-target CADRO classification (R) in this ontology — R is reserved when multiple distinct CADRO mechanisms are targeted (e.g., anti‑amyloid plus anti‑inflammatory). Note safety context: antipsychotics including aripiprazole carry a boxed warning for increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia‑related psychosis — important for trial interpretation but does not change the CADRO classification. citeturn1search10turn1search1

Web search results (selected supporting sources): - Randomized/controlled tolerability trial of IM aripiprazole in acutely agitated patients with Alzheimer’s/vascular/mixed dementia (PubMed / JAMDA). citeturn0search0turn0search1 - IM aripiprazole studies showing rapid efficacy for acute agitation in psychiatric populations. citeturn0search2turn0search4 - Pharmacology review describing aripiprazole as a D2 partial agonist and 5‑HT1A partial agonist with additional serotonergic/adrenoceptor affinities. citeturn0search5 - Product/label and safety information noting increased mortality risk in elderly patients with dementia‑related psychosis (boxed warning). citeturn1search10turn1search1
